deck_style_notes.notation_policy: ≤2 operational formulas per method slide; define symbols inline

slides.title: Time‑Domain Statistical Features
slides.objective: Introduce simple statistical features (RMS, peak, crest factor, kurtosis, skewness) for vibration analysis.

text_blocks.label: bullets
content: RMS and energy
Peak and crest factor
Kurtosis and skewness

visuals.description: Time trend of RMS and kurtosis for healthy vs faulty signal

callouts.label: rule_of_thumb
callouts.content: Use RMS for overall energy and crest factor/kurtosis for impulsiveness

callouts.label: sanity_check
callouts.content: Normalise signals before computing shape metrics

talking_points: Explain why simple statistics can reveal changes in signal behaviour over time.
Introduce RMS as a measure of energy; peak and crest factor for impulsiveness; kurtosis and skewness for shape of distribution.
Preview how trending these features aids condition monitoring.

slides.title: Detecting Degradation with Time‑Domain Features
slides.objective: Motivate time‑domain feature extraction with industrial examples of bearing degradation and impulsive faults.

text_blocks.label: bullets
content: RMS increases as vibration energy grows
Crest factor and kurtosis rise when impulsive faults emerge
Skewness indicates asymmetry in vibration due to alignment issues

visuals.description: Trend of kurtosis increasing as faults develop

callouts.label: rule_of_thumb
callouts.content: Compute features on consistent window lengths for trending

callouts.label: sanity_check
callouts.content: Remove DC offset before computing shape metrics

talking_points: Describe how RMS and kurtosis trends can reveal machine degradation before failure.
Explain why crest factor is sensitive to sharp impulses like bearing defects.
Highlight the need for normalisation and consistent windowing when computing features.

slides.title: Black‑Box Feature Extraction: Inputs, Knobs, Outputs, Failure
slides.objective: Define how to compute time‑domain statistical features and avoid pitfalls.

text_blocks.label: bullets
content: Inputs: signal window x[n] of length L
Knobs: window_length, overlap, threshold for peaks
Outputs: RMS, peak, crest factor, kurtosis, skewness
Failure: features misinterpreted if signal not normalised or window size inconsistent

callouts.label: rule_of_thumb
callouts.content: Use sliding windows with 50% overlap to capture trends

callouts.label: sanity_check
callouts.content: Demean and normalise amplitude before computing kurtosis and skewness

talking_points: Describe how to segment the signal into windows and compute features in each window.
Explain how crest factor, kurtosis and skewness quantify impulsiveness and distribution shape.
Identify failure modes: misinterpreting features when the signal is not pre‑processed or window sizes vary across segments.

slides.title: Demo: Feature Extraction and Trending
slides.objective: Show how to compute time‑domain features on a simulated vibration signal and track changes over time.

text_blocks.label: bullets
content: Generate a vibration signal with increasing impulsiveness over time
Compute RMS, kurtosis and skewness in sliding windows
Plot feature trends and identify when they exceed thresholds

visuals.description: Trend plots of RMS and kurtosis over time with threshold lines

callouts.label: sanity_check
callouts.content: Observe feature trends rise when impulsive events start

talking_points: Walk through the demo: constructing the signal, segmenting it and computing features.
Interpret the trend plots: note when features exceed nominal thresholds indicating potential faults.
Encourage students to modify window_length and observe how trends change.

expected_output: Feature trend plots and threshold flags

slides.title: Failure Modes: Misusing Statistical Features
slides.objective: Discuss pitfalls such as over‑reliance on peak values and ignoring normalisation.

text_blocks.label: bullets
content: Peak values can be misleading in noisy signals
Kurtosis and skewness depend on amplitude scaling
Changing window lengths across samples breaks comparability

visuals.description: Feature trends before and after normalisation and consistent windowing

callouts.label: rule_of_thumb
callouts.content: Normalise signals (e.g., divide by RMS) before computing shape metrics

callouts.label: sanity_check
callouts.content: Keep window lengths consistent across time to make features comparable

talking_points: Explain why peak measurements may be dominated by noise and not represent fault severity.
Show how kurtosis and skewness values change if the signal amplitude is scaled.
Emphasise consistent windowing when trending features over time.

links_to_code.what_to_run: Experiment with normalisation and window length

slides.title: Exercise: Compute and Interpret Features
slides.objective: Allow learners to compute time‑domain features on synthetic data and identify fault onset.

text_blocks.label: bullets
content: Generate a synthetic vibration signal with increasing impulsiveness
Compute RMS, crest factor, kurtosis and skewness on sliding windows
Plot trends and identify when features exceed nominal thresholds
Fill in a table with feature values and fault detection time

visuals.description: Template recording window_length, RMS, crest factor, kurtosis, skewness and detected fault time

callouts.label: rule_of_thumb
callouts.content: Use 50% overlap and windows of at least 0.2 s for vibration signals

callouts.label: sanity_check
callouts.content: Ensure signals are demeaned before computing shape metrics

talking_points: Explain the exercise tasks and encourage using different window lengths and overlaps.
Guide learners to compute features, plot trends and fill in the table.
Discuss which features detect the fault earliest and why.

links_to_code.what_to_run: Modify window_length and threshold values in demo
expected_output: Completed table, feature trends and detection times

slides.title: Summary & Quick Quiz
slides.objective: Reinforce time‑domain feature concepts and test understanding.

text_blocks.label: bullets
content: RMS measures energy; crest factor and kurtosis capture impulsiveness
Skewness indicates asymmetry in vibration
Consistent windowing and normalisation are essential for comparable features

visuals.description: Recap of time‑domain feature extraction workflow

callouts.content:
1. What does an increasing RMS trend suggest?
2. How is the crest factor computed?

talking_points: Summarise the importance of simple statistical features for condition monitoring.
Ask quiz questions and discuss answers with learners.
